(Government claimed) |casualties2=37 killed }} {{Campaignbox Moro conflict}} The '''Battle of Tipo-Tipo''' is an ongoing military engagement that is taking place in [[Tipo-Tipo, Basilan|Tipo-Tipo]], [[Basilan Island]] which started on April 9, 2016, between forces of the [[Philippine Army]] and members of the [[Abu Sayyaf]] militant group. The battle resulted in dozens of casualties, with at least 18 Philippine soldiers and 5 militants reported killed and more than 70 others injured in total. It was the largest single loss of life for the Army since the beginning of the year, and came just one day after the group had released an Italian hostage.{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/11/world/asia/18-philippine-soldiers-killed-in-firefight-with-militant-group.html?ref=world|title=18 Philippine Soldiers Killed in Firefight With Militant Group|date=10 April 2016|accessdate=10 April 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/04/09/18-filipino-soldiers-killed-52-others-wounded-in-clash.html|title=18 Filipino soldiers killed, 52 others wounded in clash|date=10 April 2016|accessdate=10 April 2016|work=[[Fox News]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/18-philippine-troops-killed-in-clash-with-abu-sayyaf-fighters|title=18 Philippine troops killed in clash with Abu Sayyaf fighters|date=10 April 2016|accessdate=10 April 2016|work=[[Straits Times]]}} ==Background== [[Abu Sayyaf]] became a part of [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] in 2014 when nearly all of its members, including its leader Isnilon Hapilon, [[Bay'ah|pledged allegiance]] to the said group. The Philippine government dismissed this news as a threat. The Philippine military pledged that on 9 April 2016, which that day is also the [[Araw ng Kagitingan|National Day of Valor]], they will conduct an offensive aimed at wiping out the militant groups in the island. ==Battle== Clashes erupted around 8am on April 9 as troops entered Tipo-Tipo in search of Abu Sayyaf insurgents. A group of more than 100 militants ambushed the government forces, sparking a 10-hour firefight, according to Major Filemon Tan, a spokesman for the Western Mindanao Command of the Philippine Army. News reports indicated an entire platoon was wiped out, with at least four soldiers being beheaded by militants. Among those killed were Ubaida Hapilon, son of the regional commander Isnilon Hapilon, as well as Mohammad Khattab, a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] bomb maker and extremist preacher. On April 13 ongoing operations conducted resulted in the death toll of 24 Abu Sayaf members. President [[Benigno Aquino III|Aquino]] visited injured soldiers in Zamboanga.http://cnnphilippines.com/regional/2016/04/13/Aquino-Basilan-clash-Abu-Sayyaf-AFP.html As of April 14, the AFP said that 31 militants have been killed.http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/04/14/AFP-Abu-Sayyaf-ISIS-Basilan-clash.html On the 8th July, [[CNN]] report that "the fighting in Basilan that began Wednesday night is affecting three towns: [[Tipo-Tipo, Basilan|Tipo-Tipo]], [[Ungkaya Pukan, Basilan|Ungkaya Pukan]] and [[Al-Barka, Basilan|Al-Barka]]" and that "the armed men fighting authorities in Basilan are led by the notorious Abu Sayyaf leaders Puruji Indama and [[Isnilon Hapilon]]"http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/07/09/Thousands-flee-amid-Basilan-clashes.html On the 8th July, the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] released a report on the fighting, claiming 40 Filipino soldiers had been killed in eight days of clashes and that the battle involved heavy artillery fire and airstrikes. ==Reactions== {{expand section|date=April 2016}} ===ISIS involvement claim=== The [[Islamic State of Iraq and Syria]] claimed responsibility for the clash in April 9. In a statement by the group's Amaq news agency dated in April 13, it said that the militants involved in the clash in April 9 had bombed 7 trucks of the Philippine military, killing 100 soldiers with only three casualties in the militants' side. The Philippine security officials dismissed the claim as propaganda saying that there were "many gaps and inconsistencies" in ISIS' statement. Brigadier General Restituto Padilla, military spokesperson said in an April 14 report by ''Reuters'' that only 18 soldiers and 28 Abu Sayaff soldiers have died at that time and no truck exploded. Padilla also said that the military hasn't established that Abu Sayaff and ISIS are linked organizations.{{cite news|last1=Mogato|first1=Manuel|title=Philippines rejects Islamic State's claim it killed 100 troops|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-islamic-state-idUSKCN0XA21K|accessdate=14 April 2016|agency=Reuters|date=14 April 2016}}{{cite news|title=Philippines dismisses ISIS claims of killing 100 soldiers|url=http://www.lawyerherald.com/articles/42533/20160414/philippines-dismisses-isis-claims-killing-100-soldiers.htm|accessdate=14 April 2016|publisher=Lawyer Herald|date=14 April 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{History of the Moro conflict}} {{Moro conflict}} [[Category:20th-century conflicts|Tipo-Tipo]] [[Category:21st-century conflicts|Tipo-Tipo]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in the Philippines]] [[Category:History of Basilan]] [[Category:Military history of the Philippines|Tipo-Tipo]] [[Category:Moro]] [[Category:Rebellions in the Philippines]] [[Category:Wars involving the Philippines|Tipo-Tipo]] [[Category:Moro conflict| ]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016|Tipo-Tipo]] [[Category:2016 in the Philippines]]
